resources.string: Visit phyphox.org to create more advanced experiments including data analysis and share them with colleagues, students and friends.
Buffer size (number of values to be stored)
Sensor rate (in Hz, 0 = as fast as possible)

Phyphox will use the first language available from your preferred languages list. To change your preferences, go to your Android \"settings\" below. To learn which languages are available and how you can help, select \"visit website\".

Please be careful not to damage your phone while experimenting. Please take special care to avoid dropping it on hard surfaces and do not expose it to excessive magnetic fields. The authors of phyphox are not responsible for any damage to your phone.
phyphox has been created at the 2nd Institute of Physics at the RWTH Aachen University.

Development and Concept:
Dr. Sebastian Staacks
Concept:
Prof. Christoph Stampfer
Design:
Frank Posthoff (A.NikoPol)
Programming:
Camilla Lummerzheim
Jonas Gessner

The web-interface for remote access uses the JavaScript libraries \"jQuery\" ((c) 2005, 2014 jQuery Foundation, Inc.), \"flot\" ((c) 2007-2014 IOLA and Ole Laursen) and \"Axis Labels Plugin for flot\" ((c) 2010 Xuan Luo), all available under the MIT licence.

is not available. Usually this means, that your device simply does not have this type of sensor.
Do you want to delete this experiment from your collection?

You are about to enable remote access to the acquired data. You should only do so on a trusted network! Also note, that direct access between devices may not be possible on many corporate or university networks.

For best security and performance you should connect to this device via a tethering option (mobile hotspot).

After pressing ok, you can access your measurement from any web browser on the same network.
Remote access enabled. Access this experiment from the following URL: \n%1$s
This experiment has been opened from a remote source. Do you want to add it to your experiment collection?
You can save the state of this experiment including your data to your collection or share it with a third-party app.
State has been saved to your collection.
Pick the data sets to export.
Check experiment info to learn how to use this experiment.
